Web 2.0

The participative social web

As it stands, we are currently in the second generation of the web. Otherwise known as web 2.0, it’s defined as the “Participative social web”. Web 2.0 focuses on user-generated content, the web as a platform, and software as a service (SaaS).

Compared to Web 1.0, this version of the web is interactive, flexible, and social.

BUT WAIT THERE’S MORE!

How Web 2.0 spurred an influx of consumerism.

Before web 2.0 there was only a hand-full of ways a company could market their products. But with the digital age, businesses could sell “niche” goods and turn a profit from them. According to Britannica “The vast quantity of niche books makes up for the greater sales of a few popular titles—makes up, that is, in the new digital environment of e-commerce, where counter space is no longer limited.”

Software as a Service

Many leading software applications have transitioned to a SaaS model with compatibility across various devices. Companies like Microsoft, and Adobe Creative Cloud to Netflix, Zoom, and Spotify, SaaS is a common model that offers web-based software applications on demand for a monthly subscription.

Rise of social media & video/image sharing sites

Social media networks allow every user to easily share content, chat with other users, and respond to new content in real-time with interactivity and user-generated content. Popular networks such as Twitter, Instagram, Facebook, and TikTok, are some of the most highly visited sites on the web.

Second Browser War

2004-2022 acording to wikipedia

  • After the first browser war, Netscape got discontinued. Suggesting it’s users to migrate to Firefox. It ended with Microsoft’s Internet explorer as the reigning champion. Followed by firefox being the only other competitor (at about 30% market share)

  • Apple introduces Safari (with WebKit) and Microsoft discontinued Internet Explorer on the MAC platform. At the same time, safari released for windows, but was discontinued shortly in 2010.

  • Chrome gets released by google harnessing apple’s WebKit and a faster JavaScript engine. Followed up by Internet Explorer’s first major drop in market share.

  • In 2012, Chrome, Internet Explorer and Firefox repeatedly overtake each other in market share. But after chrome overtook firefox, the competition intensified.

  • A few years later in 2015, Microsoft discontinued the production of newer versions of Internet Explorer. By this point, Chrome overtook all other browsers as the browser with the highest usage share.

  • In June 2022, Microsoft permanently retired Internet Explorer in favor of Microsoft Edge as their sole browser.

  • By the end of 2022 according to gs.statcounter.com chrome is the leading browser at 65.4%, followed by Safari at 18.71%, Edge at 4.46% and FireFox at 3%.

Disadvantages

Two steps forward, one step back

Unfortunately, there are a lot of disadvantages to the Internet acting more like an open forum. Through the expansion of social media, we have seen an increase in online stalking, doxing, cyberbullying, identity theft, and other online crimes. There is also the threat of misinformation spreading among users, whether that's through open-source information-sharing sites or on social media.

Individuals may blame Web 2.0 for misinformation, information overload, or the unreliability of what people read. As almost anyone can post anything via various blogs, social media, or out With web 2.0, there is an increased risk of confusion on what is real and what sources may be deemed as reliable.

As a result, Web 2.0 brings about higher stakes regarding communication. It's more likely to have fake accounts, spammers, forgers, or hackers that attempt to steal information, imitate personas, or trick unsuspecting Web 2.0 users into following their agenda. As Web 2.0 doesn't always and can't verify information, there is a heightened risk for bad actors to take advantage of opportunities.

Benefits

It’s not all bad

This development of technology has allowed users to share their thoughts and opinions with others, creating new ways of organizing and connecting with other people. One of the largest advantages of Web 2.0 is improved communication through web applications that enhances interactivity, collaboration, and knowledge sharing.

This is most evidence through social networking, where individuals armed with a Web 2.0 connection can publish content, share ideas, extract information, and subscribe to various informational feeds.

Web 2.0 also bring about a certain level of equity. Most individuals have an equal chance of posting their views and comments, and each individual may build a network of contacts. Because information may be transmit more quickly under Web 2.0 compared to prior methods.

Reflections

Is it this the end? Not really...

Web 2.0 brough new ease when it came to participatory, collaboration and distribution practices. This in tern enabled a surge of formal and informal activities on the web. While allowing users to have more interaction. But this came at the lost of them losing control.

Now that technology has integrated itself into our everyday lives, it’s hard to imagine a life without it. They say that the internet is forever, but it’s more like an open sea of information. You need to parse through it’s waves to retrieve what you are searching for.

There are endless threads of information about what’s not covered here. From software wars to the deep web, there's much more to explore. Just google it! (Unless you’re part of the 16% of users who don’t use it)

Don’t take what is written here as the only truth, this page is nothing but a blimp on the surface of what we know as web 2.0.
